text: the mayor believed coming into office
that the single most important thing
that he could do was to improve the
educational system he felt that it was
absolutely a horrible horrible shame
that we were allowing 1 million children
to go fundamentally
uneducated and how you then go about
solving that problem there are lots of
different theories and some things are
tested and others are not but it started
with an ideological position that the
way in which we were dealing with the
problem was fundamentally wrong and that
there had to be accountability that it
had to vest in in the mayor and as a
result you kind of built a program
around that point of view now frequently
we did look start and look at things
analytically when we came into office
and looked at the economic condition we
did a very careful analysis of where we
thought we could compete and that was
less uh ideological and sort of more
analytical but I think it would be a
mistake to assume that those two things
really are separate what he didn't do is
make those decisions politically and
that's what distinguishes this mayor
from I think any other mayor certainly
we've ever had and virtually any other
politician
um came in not being beholden to anyone
because he hadn't accepted campaign
contributions but more fundamentally
just has this view that his job is to do
the right thing for New Yorkers even if
there is a negative consequence for him
politically and I will tell you in the
first four years um that I was in
government um in leading up to a
reelection bid I can't even count on one
hand the number of times that a decision
was taken where there was anything
expressed about the political or
election ramifications of that decision
people have no idea what an enormous
asset that is um for the city and it how
it allows you to move an aggressive
reform agenda forward uh we uh benefited
from um not just the fact that the mayor
paid for his own election set that sign
but his mindset which really is to just
do the right thing political
consequences be
damned I think there's a fair amount of
u truth to it uh now you have to Define
what you mean um does it mean that you
actually have plans that you lay out in
detail and then EX execute on that's
running something like a business does
that work reasonably well in government
recognizing how much more complex
government actually is yes it does um
though sophisticated communication
techniques um and marketing of your
ideas help do partnering with other
people who can potentially bring value
whether it is from the private sector or
Foundation
or other parties in the public sector
something that business tends to do
better than the private sector does yeah
does um holding yourself accountable and
Reporting on how you did which is more
of a public sector a private sector
approach rather than a public sector
approach um does that work in government
absolutely you know the mayor issues a
report card on how he's done relative to
his campaign promises we have put
literally every piece of information
about how government is doing on the
internet and a city-wide performance
reporting system which we're quite proud
of which kind of the Bloomberg for
government um so all of those
disciplines brought from the private
sector to the public sector can work but
you fundamentally also have to recognize
that government is different government
in many ways is harder on any one issue
and you're dealing with hundreds at a
time there are dozens perhaps of Waring
parties all of whom have different
agendas some of which aren't clear at
all some of which are
irreconcilable and in many ways your job
is to manage conflict to reach an
objective and that is a very difficult
thing so you make a mistake coming in
thinking oh yes I'll just bring the same
disciplines from government from
business into government and it'll work
that's not true you have to be sensitive
to the very significant differences
between the
two you know I I I find first of all I
would uh really object to the comment
about Manhattan being the most racially
uh segregated place I I think New York
is in fact the most open place anywhere
in the world and one of the things we
worked very hard on over uh the six
years I was there and I know the mayor
and his team have continued to work hard
on it is building neighborhoods across
the city that are more economically
diverse more racially diverse uh and I I
do believe that we have been quite
successful in doing that our housing
plan uh built affordable housing for f
is is building affordable housing for
500,000 New Yorkers I mean that's more
people than uh the city of Atlanta has
and every single one of those people
will be living in a place they otherwise
wouldn't have been able to to afford to
live in now one problem we have had over
the last several years it's been
mitigated somewhat now by the economic
crisis is you know because there's so
many people who wanted to come here uh
because of the laws of supply and demand
do fundamentally operate prices go up
and that has an unfortunate consequence
of uh pricing people out of the market
and some neighborhoods gentrifying
things on the other hand it really is
the price of success and the way we
responded to it was by developing these
programs that opened up opportunities
for hundreds of thousands of people uh
but in general it's very hard to fight
the market I don't think there are very
many of us who would prefer the
situation we have today in the economy
and the consequences it has for people
at every level of the economic spectrum
to what we had a few years ago overall
